sect2.title: 34 Approaches to the Identification of Aerobic Gram-Negative Bacteria*
sect2.para: Aerobic Gram-negative bacteria encompass some of the most frequently encountered bacteria in the clinical microbiology laboratory, and approximately one-third of the chapters in the Bacteriology section of thisManual are assigned to these bacteria. Medically important pathogens include the Enterobacterales (notably Escherichia coli, Klebsiella spp., and Salmonella spp.), glucose nonfermenters (e.g., Pseudomonas aeruginosa, Acinetobacter baumannii), fastidious organisms (e.g., Bordetella pertussis, Haemophilus influenzae, Legionella spp., and Neisseria spp.), and remarkable zoonoses (Bartonella henselae, Francisella tularensis). Most of these bacteria are rod-shaped, but Neisseria spp. and Moraxella catarrhalis are diplococci, and some organisms, in particular fastidious organisms, are coccobacilli (H. influenzae). The description of aerobic Gram-negative bacteria is long established, based on culture conditions and the failure to retain crystal violet-iodine complex by Gram’s staining method. Cellular morphology is of less importance in this context, as curved or spiral-shaped rods are excluded from the group and discussed in chapters 59 through 63 of this Manual. In addition to categorical characteristics, the delineation of aerobic Gram-negative bacteria has been influenced by clinical significance and, more recently, taxonomic scrutiny based on DNA sequencing. It is helpful to recapitulate the characteristics of the group in the context of laboratory practice and nomenclatural changes.

sect3.title: PROKARYOTIC NOMENCLATURE
sect3.para: Naming is an essential component of scientific and clinical investigations (1), and prokaryotic names are regulated by the International Code of Nomenclature of Prokaryotes (ICNP) (2, 3). The principles aim at stability of names, and avoid the useless creation of names. Names of all taxa are Latin or latinized words treated as Latin regardless of their origin. The name of a taxon should not be changed without sufficient reason, and a taxon can bear only one correct name, based upon valid publication, legitimacy, and priority of publication. The ICNP distinguishes five categories of names: legitimate, illegitimate, effectively published, validly published, and correct. Legitimate names are formed according to the rules of the code; validly published means registered either in the Approved Lists, or by subsequent original publication in the International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology (IJSEM) or its Validation Lists. Correct names will be discussed below. To comply with the principles, names that are effectively, but not validly, published will be provided between quotation marks. Whenever possible, the type of a species is a designated strain. The type strain is made up of living cultures of an organism, descended from a strain designated as the nomenclatural type.

sect2.title: Genome
sect2.para: Taxonomy is an organizing principle of biology ideally based on evolutionary relationships among organisms (4). An average nucleotide identity (ANI) threshold of 95 to 96% has emerged as a putative standard for quantitative delineation of species (5, 6), whereas assignment of species to higher ranks (genus to phylum) has not been settled. The Genome Taxonomy Database (GTDB) depicts bacterial phylogeny inferred from concatenation of selected amino acids from 120 ubiquitous single-copy proteins sourced from the publicly available genomes from the National Center for Biotechnology Information (NCBI) and compiles genome groups in ANI-based species clusters (7); at the time of writing, the database comprises 311,480 bacterial genomes organized into 62,291 species clusters (https://gtdb.ecogenomic.org/). Species clusters without a type strain genome are assigned an alphanumeric or Latin-suffixed placeholder name. Taxon names above the rank of genus that are not monophyletic in the GTDB reference tree, or whose placement is unstable, are appended with an alphabetic suffix. Figure 1 shows a tree built according to the same methodological criteria as a GTDB reference tree (4), depicting the genomes of 61 type strains of aerobic Gram-negative species (chapters 35 to 52), plus 94 genomes of type strains of bacterial species described in other parts of the Bacteriology section of the Manual.

sect2.para: Aerobic Gram-negative bacteria are primarily “Proteobacteria,” but aerobic “Bacteroidetes” (Capnocytophaga, Chryseobacterium, and Elizabethkingia) are also considered (chapters 36 and 47). Fourteen species from five families of the order Enterobacterales cluster according to family in Fig. 1 (Hafnia alvei is the sole representative of Hafniaceae). Plesiomonas shigelloides (chapter 40) has historically been difficult to place in a specific taxonomic group. It was originally published as a species of the genus Pseudomonas; while Plesiomonas denotes a neighboring monad (to Aeromonas) (https://lpsn.dsmz.de/), genus Plesiomonas was placed within the family Vibrionaceae before transfer to the family Enterobacteriaceae (8). The conspicuous position of this species in Fig.1 is in accordance with the analysis of Adeolu et al., i.e., that the genus Plesiomonas has limited association with other members of the order Enterobacterales and may not belong in the order at all (9). The genomic examination supports long-established practices that exclude oxidase-positive Gram-negative rods from the family Enterobacteriaceae.

sect2.title: Nomenclatural Challenges and the Responsibility of the Clinical Microbiology Laboratory
sect2.para: In contrast to the regulation of names by the ICNP, there is no official taxonomic classification of prokaryotes. Among a set of validly published names for a taxon, the List of Prokaryotic names with Standing in Nomenclature (LPSN;https://lpsn.dsmz.de/) selects a certain name as the correct name. The correct name is usually, but not always, the most recent of the validly published names. There are three validly published names based on the same type (i.e., homotypic synonyms) for a species known as Actinobacillus actinomycetemcomitans (2), Haemophilus actinomycetemcomitans (10), and Aggregatibacter actinomycetemcomitans (11), in addition to the effectively published description from 1912, “Bacterium actinomycetemcomitans” (12). The most recent name, Aggregatibacter actinomycetemcomitans, is the correct name according to LPSN, with the kind note that one of the other validly published names is the correct name if this species is regarded as a separate species within the genus Actinobacillus or Haemophilus, respectively.

A special case is the classification of genusOchrobactrum as a later heterotypic synonym of genus Brucella (13, 14). Ochrobactrum anthropi is a saprophytic soil bacterium and an opportunistic pathogen, briefly mentioned in chapter 47. In contrast, members of the genus Brucella are detailed in a separate chapter because of high pathogenicity, laboratory safety considerations, and notification to public health authorities (chapter 50). Reporting of Brucella species may elicit serious clinical concerns, and it is questionable whether reclassification of Ochrobactrum is helpful. Additionally, the scientific argument for renaming of Ochrobactrum as Brucella has been disputed (15). While the two taxa have similar core genomes, their accessory genomes are unrelated. Brucella species contain a closed pangenome of ≤3.4 Mb, whereas Ochrobactrum species contain an open pangenome involved in lateral transfer, with genome sizes of ≥4.7 Mb. Moreover, the organisms have different habitats and belong to different risk groups. Similar concerns may be raised regarding reassignment of Enterobacter aerogenes (with chromosomally encoded, inducible AmpC) as Klebsiella aerogenes (16). The risk that this may trigger an increased but objectionable prescription of cephalosporins, because of anamnestic success with treatment of other Klebsiella species that do not harbor an inducible ampC gene on their chromosome (see chapter 72), must be addressed by close consultation with prescribers, antimicrobial stewardship teams, and infection control committees.

The lack of an official classification obliges the bacteriologist to choose between names according to scientific judgment. According to the College of American Pathologists (MIC.11375 Taxonomy Changes Phase I), the laboratory is required to review taxonomic changes that potentially affect the choice and/or the interpretative breakpoints of appropriate antimicrobials. Pending recommendations from national or international societies, or from health authorities, it is advisable to introduce nomenclatural changes in a thoughtful way. There may be limited acclaim for being the first laboratory to report culture ofBrucella anthropi from a clinical sample, while the publication of K. aerogenes appears scientifically justified and can be introduced at a careful pace.

sect3.title: PHENOTYPIC TEST METHODS AND IDENTIFICATION SCHEMES

sect2.title: Gram Stain
sect2.para: The Gram stain is the first step in the preliminary identification of a cultured bacterium. The method separates Gram-positive and -negative bacteria, although not all bacteria are classified by the technique. The classical relevance of the staining method is demonstrated by the suggestion of bacterial “divisions” (“Firmicutes,” “Gracilicutes,” and Mollicutes) in 1978, when cell wall structures were identified as the biologic basis of Gram stain reactivity (4, 17). Gram-positive bacteria belong to bacterial phyla “Actinobacteria” and “Firmicutes,” which were recently renamed and validated as Actinomycetota and Bacillota (18, 19). The biological significance of the cell envelope has prompted alternative designations, such as monoderm and diderm, to herald the presence of single or two membranes in Gram-positive and -negative bacteria, respectively. Whether the monoderm or the diderm phenotype is ancestral is disputed (20, 21). Several true Gram-negative genera belong to the classically Gram-positive phylum “Firmicutes” (class Negativicutes). Others, such as Moryella, present as Gram negative, but are structurally Gram positive (22). Also, genetically Gram-positive bacteria such as Gardnerella vaginalis (chapter 28) and some Lactobacillus spp. (chapter 55) appear Gram negative in routine testing. Among commonly detected Gram negatives, Acinetobacter spp. often stain Gram variable.

Gram-negative, aerobic diplococci or coccobacilli may suggest identification asNeisseria and Moraxella spp. (chapters 35 and 47) or H. influenzae and Acinetobacter spp. (chapters 37 and 47), respectively.

sect2.title: Oxygen Requirement and Fermentation
sect2.para: It is a truism that oxygen is an oxidant, but coexistence with this chemical element varies between organisms. Aerobic respiration requires oxygen in order to create ATP, but obligate aerobic bacteria can multiply in the absence of oxygen if an alternative electron acceptor is provided in the medium. Fermentation produces enzymatic changes in organic substrates, and the metabolic process is common to prokaryotes and eukaryotes. Louis Pasteur conceptualized fermented beverages to be the result of the action of microorganisms, and defined the process as respiration in the absence of air (23). Fermentation and anaerobic metabolism have been considered synonymous since Pasteur demonstrated that acids and alcohols are major end products of carbohydrate degradation when oxygen is excluded from the system. Obligate anaerobic bacteria will not grow in the presence of oxygen, but loss of viability at ambient air varies considerably between anaerobic bacteria. Finally, microaerophilic organisms require environments with reduced levels of dioxygen (typically 2 to 10% O2) for optimal growth. Thus, microbial categorization is linked to practical conditions for optimal or achievable bacterial growth on standardized media, rather than bacterial use of oxygen for production of energy. Obligate aerobic bacteria (or nonfermenters) grow in the presence, but not absence, of atmospheric oxygen; obligate anaerobic bacteria grow in the absence, but not presence, of atmospheric oxygen; aerobic fermenters (or facultative anaerobes) can be cultured in both the presence and absence of atmospheric oxygen; and microaerophiles have optimal growth at reduced levels of oxygen. The designation “aerobic bacteria” excludes obligate anaerobes while encompassing the three other types.

Non-glucose-fermenting organisms are commonly detected in clinical specimens. Initial clues that an aerobic Gram-negative bacterium is a non-glucose fermenter include a positive cytochrome oxidase reaction and lack of growth in the absence of oxygen, but the oxidative-fermentative characteristic is ultimately determined by inoculation of slanted solid media (e.g., KIA or TSI slant; see below for further details). It should be noted that there are some notable non-glucose fermenters that are cytochrome oxidase negative, such asA. baumannii complex and Stenotrophomonas maltophilia.

sect2.title: Glucose-Fermenting Gram-Negative Bacteria (Facultative Anaerobes)
sect2.para: From a practical perspective, most facultatively anaerobic glucose fermenters can be separated in two groups, theEnterobacterales and the oxidase-positive fermenters.

In 2016, the orderEnterobacterales was circumscribed, comprising the families Enterobacteriaceae, Erwiniaceae, Pectobacteriaceae, Yersiniaceae, Hafniaceae, Morganellaceae, and Budviciaceae (9). The phylogenetic reconstruction was based on 1,548 core proteins present in 179 representative members of 49 genera with validly published names, and it was supported by comparison of 16S rRNA gene sequences and ribosomal proteins and the presence of conserved signature insertions/deletions (CSIs) (Fig. 2). These families include some of the most clinically relevant aerobic Gram-negative bacteria and are described in chapters 39 to 44 of this Manual. Bacteria of the family Enterobacteriaceae are the most commonly identified Gram-negative bacteria in clinical samples (chapters 39 to 42). Morganellaceae (chapter 41) and Yersiniaceae (chapter 42) are also repeatedly encountered, while Hafniaceae and Erwiniaceae are rare; the two last families (Budviciaceae and Pectobacteriaceae) may not be detected.

A positive oxidase test for an aerobic glucose fermenter suggests identification asAeromonas, Plesiomonas, or Vibrio spp. Halotolerance (growth in the presence of high salt concentrations) signifies Vibrio spp. that (except Vibrio metschnikovii) are also positive for catalase and oxidase (chapter 44). A positive oxidase test, in the absence of halotolerance, indicates Plesiomonas spp. (chapter 40) or Aeromonas spp. (chapter 43).

Glucose fermentation can be assessed using the KIA or TSI slant by stab-inoculating growth of a Gram-negative bacterium of interest. Focusing on KIA: if there is no yellow color in the KIA tube, the organism is negative for both lactose and glucose fermentation (i.e., the organism is a nonfermenter). If both the butt of the tube and the slant are yellow on the next day, the isolate is positive for the fermentation of both lactose and glucose. If only the butt is yellow, the organism is negative for lactose and positive for glucose metabolism. For the TSI slant, a third sugar, sucrose, is incorporated, allowing the slant to assess lactose and/or sucrose fermentation. Fermentation of lactose, trehalose, or xylose is characteristic of many species of the familiesEnterobacteriaceae (chapters 38 through 40) and Yersiniaceae (chapter 42); the absence of fermentation of these three sugars is characteristic of several species in the families Hafniaceae and Morganellaceae (chapter 41). The use of KIA/TSI slants as part of the workup of Gram-negative organisms has largely been discontinued due to the introduction of matrix-assisted laser desorption ionization–time of flight mass spectrometry (MALDI-TOF MS), which provides more rapid and specific identification.

Practically speaking, MacConkey agar, or a similar Gram-negative selective agar, is used in most clinical laboratories as part of the standard media for culture setup. The original MacConkey agar was described in 1905 for rapid identification of “Bacillus coli” as an index of pollution with sewage (24). It is widely used as a selective agar because the content of bile salts and crystal violet dye suppresses growth of most Gram-positive and some Gram-negative bacteria (e.g., Pasteurella multocida or other more fastidious Gram-negative organisms; see section below). Furthermore, the medium is differential by indicating whether or not an organism is a lactose fermenter and can aid in initial identification and workup of a Gram-negative organism. For example, as part of the workup, if a lactose fermenter is detected, that would sufficiently rule out the glucose nonfermenters, and further identification should focus on distinguishing the type of fermenter present (e.g., indole to distinguish between the lactose-fermenting Enterobacterales), whereas the lack of lactose fermentation may focus on distinguishing Enterobacterales that are non-lactose fermenters from the glucose nonfermenters with an oxidase test.

sect2.title: Non-Glucose-Fermenting Gram-Negative Bacteria (Strict Aerobes)
sect2.para: Non-glucose-fermenting Gram-negative rods (referred to as the nonfermenters for short) have emerged as important pathogens in the increasing population of patients who are immunocompromised by their underlying disease or medical treatment (25). They are ubiquitously distributed in the environment and have a propensity for intrinsic or acquired drug resistance often affecting multiple antibacterial agents. P. aeruginosa (chapter 45) and A. baumannii complex (chapter 47) are increasingly acquiring carbapenem resistance, which can result in extremely difficult-to-treat infections (26).

Nonfermenters are usually referred to as strict aerobes, although some nonfermenters, such as all denitrifiers (producing nitrogen gas from nitrite), can grow anaerobically when nitrate and/or nitrite is available as an alternative electron acceptor in oxidative respiration, instead of gaseous oxygen. Based on the presence of oxidase and pyoverdin, plus four biochemical tests (production of H2S, indole, trypsin, and pyrrolidonyl aminopeptidase), the dichotomous identification algorithm for aerobically growing nonfermenters provided in the 11th edition of this Manual discriminates eight groups of Gram-negative nonfermenters (Table 1). Production of pyoverdins is a strong characteristic of Pseudomonas spp.; the yellow-green, water-soluble, fluorescent pigment is a powerful Fe3+ scavenger and transporter. As a fluorescent pigment, it represents a ready marker for bacterial differentiation, and as a siderophore, it plays an important physiological function in satisfying the absolute iron requirement of these bacteria (27). Fluorescent pyoverdins are often visualized as green pigment on Mueller-Hinton agar. Based on a battery of additional phenotypic tests, it is possible to identify 90 species of Gram-negative nonfermenters originating from 37 genera of two phyla (“Bacteroidetes” and “Proteobacteria”) (28). Laboratories working with these organisms can consult the 11th edition of this Manual for phenotypic tests (28), plus the relevant chapters (chapters 45 to 48).

sect2.para: Manual biochemical systems and MALDI-TOF MS, manual biochemical methods are rarely used for identification in the clinical laboratory. However, the cytochrome oxidase test is a rapid test that can be helpful in preliminary identification of the most commonly encountered nonfermenters in the clinical microbiology laboratory.Pseudomonas and Burkholderia spp. are oxidase positive, whereas Acinetobacter spp. and Stenotrophomonas maltophilia are oxidase negative.

sect2.title: Gram-Negative Bacteria Not Recovered on Selective Gram-Negative Media
sect2.para: Some Gram-negative organisms are not recovered on selective Gram-negative media, such as MacConkey agar, as they are inhibited by crystal violet and bile salts or due to their fastidious nature.P. multocida is commonly detected in samples from animal bites and may be the dominant bacterium in such specimens, in particular cat bites (chapter 36). In samples from animal bites, rapid growth on nonselective media of grayish-white colonies that do not attain the size of colonies of Enterobacterales suggests this identification, supported by a positive oxidase test and by lack of growth on MacConkey agar. Pasteurella spp. are generally commensals of animals, but Pasteurella bettyae is a rare human uropathogen. Pasteurella spp. must be distinguished from Capnocytophaga spp. from animal bite wounds, as it too is not recovered on MacConkey agar. However, the Gram stain demonstrating a thin Gram-negative bacillus would suggest Capnocytophaga spp., whereas Pasteurella spp. are small Gram-negative coccobacilli.

Other fastidious Gram-negative bacteria, such as the “HACEK” organisms (Haemophilus, Aggregatibacter, Cardiobacterium, Eikenella, and Kingella), exhibit poor growth on sheep blood agar, in addition to lack of growth on MacConkey (chapters 36 and 37). The HACEK organisms are a recognized but unusual cause of infective endocarditis, responsible for 1.4 to 3% of cases (29–31).

sect3.title: Gram-Negative Bacteria with Poor or No Growth on SBA
sect3.para: Figures 3 and 4 show dichotomous phenotypic and biochemical identification algorithms for Gram-negative bacteria that are fastidious and grow poorly or not at all on sheep blood agar (SBA). Some species of Acinetobacter and most Moraxella spp. also grow slowly on SBA, but clearly visible colonies are apparent within 48 h. H. influenzae is frequently detected in clinical samples from mucosal surfaces and the respiratory tract, while other Haemophilus and Aggregatibacter spp. are more rarely considered the causative agents of infection (chapters 37 and 36, respectively). Apart from these two genera, NAD (V-factor)-dependent Pateurellaceae species with no growth on SBA are rare in samples from humans. Selective agar for Neisseria gonorrhoeae and Neisseria meningitidis usually contains polymyxin B, lincomycin, and amphotericin B to suppress a broad range of bacteria and fungi, as well as trimethoprim to suppress swarming of Proteus; however, N. gonorrhoeae and particularly N. meningitidis from bloodstream infections are cultured on rich media lacking antimicrobials (chapter 35). M. catarrhalis is common in swabs from the eye, ear, and nasopharynx, particularly from children. These organisms produce small, grayish-white colonies that slide across the agar surface when pushed with a bacteriologic loop; the ability to hydrolyze tributyrin differentiates M. catarrhalis from the Neisseria species (32). Brucellosis remains a worldwide problem, predominantly so in developing countries. It can affect any body organ. Samples from patients suspected of brucellosis must be handled with care, because personnel handling diagnostic cultures are at risk for laboratory-acquired infection (chapter 50). In the pre-MALDI-TOF MS era, direct urease tests on signal-positive blood cultures with small Gram-negative rods could provide a presumptive diagnosis of brucellosis 2 to 3 days earlier than conventional laboratory protocols (33). Oxidase-positive coccobacilli may belong to the genus Bordetella. B. pertussis and Bordetella parapertussis are commonly detected by nucleic acid-based assays in patients with whooping cough, but Bordetella petrii and B. bronchiseptica exhibit ample growth on many media and may be identified in respiratory samples from selected patient groups (chapter 48). The oxidase reaction is positive for the slow-growing, Gram-negative rod Eikenella corrodens, which erodes the agar surface and possesses a peculiar colony morphology (i.e., pits the agar). For half a century, E. corrodens was the sole member of the genus, but four other species of Eikenella have recently been described (34, 35).

sect3.para: Additional media are necessary for initial identification of fastidious Gram-negative bacteria with no growth on SBA, particularly with respect to the important pathogensBartonella spp., B. pertussis, Francisella spp., and Legionella spp. (Fig. 4). F. tularensis has been recovered only in the Northern Hemisphere. Samples from patients suspected of tularemia must be handled with care, because personnel handling diagnostic cultures are at risk for laboratory-acquired infection (chapter 49).

sect3.title: MATRIX-ASSISTED LASER DESORPTION IONIZATION–TIME OF FLIGHT MASS SPECTROMETRY
sect3.para: Because of simplicity, cost-effectiveness, and breadth of identification possibilities, the application of MALDI-TOF MS has transformed the identification of microorganisms in routine clinical settings (chapter 6). The initial capital cost for the instrumentation is high, but the consumables used for analysis are affordable and the testing is extremely rapid. Both the MALDI-TOF MS Biotyper (Bruker) and VITEK MS (bioMérieux) systems have robust databases, available as research-use-only and in vitro diagnostic cleared versions (36, 37). The identification algorithms are not identical. The VITEK MS makes use of artificially constructed “superspectra” derived from multiple reference spectra and composed of mass peaks characteristic of a given species but absent from related species. In contrast, the MALDI-TOF MS Biotyper database encompasses a large number of mass spectrometry projections (MSPs) derived from particular and identifiable isolates.

The Bruker MBT reference library encompasses spectra from more than 600 species, but risk group 3 bacteria (or highly pathogenic bacteria [HPB]) are not covered; HPB are defined as biological agents that can cause severe human disease and present a serious hazard to health care workers. The U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) has classified the main pathogens of concern for use in bioterrorist attacks, with category A includingBacillus anthracis, F. tularensis, and Yersinia pestis and category B including Brucella species, Burkholderia mallei, Burkholderia pseudomallei, and Coxiella burnetii (38). The natural prevalence of these agents is low in most parts of the world, but intentional release can result in severe public health consequences, as was shown in the United States in 2001 (39). If detection of HPB is required by use of the Bruker platform, the database must be supplemented with the Security-Relevant (SR) library that covers 12 HPB from 10 genera; the SR library can be searched simultaneously with the Biotyper reference library (40, 41). Although these bacteria are rarely encountered in typical laboratories, B. pseudomallei will grow inconspicuously on most media. B. pseudomallei inhabits stagnant ponds and rice paddies between 20° N and 20° S latitude and accounts for 40% of infectious deaths in Thailand (38). In July 2022, the CDC announced the recovery of B. pseudomallei from environmental samples in the Gulf Coast area of Mississippi, expanding the geographic reservoir for this important pathogen (42). Chronic infections are not uncommon. This species may be misidentified as Burkholderia thailandensis.

For most species encountered in a routine clinical microbiology laboratory, current MALDI-TOF MS libraries are fairly comprehensive. Knowledge of species associated with the human body has reached a high level, but is far from complete. For example, stored clinical isolates originally identified asElizabethkingia meningoseptica may belong to subsequently named species of the genus Elizabethkingia (43). The continuous refinement of databases allows distinction of closely related species, such as the separation of “nonhemolytic Haemophilus haemolyticus” from H. influenzae (44), a discrimination barely possible by phenotypic means. A simple and safe protocol for preparing Brucella samples for MALDI-TOF MS has been published (45), although this is not universally encouraged. Laboratories in the U.S. must refer potential Brucella spp. to Laboratory Response Network laboratories for identification of Brucella species.

sect3.title: BACTERIAL IDENTIFICATION USING RIBOSOMAL RNA GENE SEQUENCES
sect3.para: The publication of theApproved Lists of Bacterial Names in 1980 authorized almost 1,800 bacterial species for retention (2). In 2002, an ad hoc committee reevaluated the species definition in bacteriology and recommended that the description of new species include almost full-length 16S rRNA gene sequences plus the results of other molecular technologies for characterization of DNA relatedness (46). In 2018, minimal standards were proposed for the use of genome data for the taxonomy of prokaryotes (47).

sect2.title: 16S Ribosomal RNA (rRNA) Gene-Based Identification
sect2.para: The small subunit (SSU) rRNA (or 16S rRNA) has long been the phylogenetic marker of choice (48). The 16S rRNA gene is present in all prokaryotic cells and is rarely subject to horizontal gene transfer. The gene is relatively large (~1,500 bp) and contains both conserved and variable regions. The variable regions evolve at a different rate from the conserved regions, allowing the distinction of different taxa. Sequences flanking the variable regions are well conserved, facilitating design of universal primers. These characteristics allow the use of 16S rRNA gene sequences for bacterial phylogeny and identification (49–51).

The gene encoding 16S rRNA consists of nine variable regions surrounded by conserved regions. The level of variation within the variable regions differs, with hot spots which display larger numbers of mutations. These areas differ among bacterial species, and different regions provide varying phylogenetic resolution for different groups of bacteria (49). Determination of the full-length sequence of the 16S rRNA gene has been limited by either cost or sequencing technology, and thus often only partial sequences are analyzed. Due to the variation in informative nucleotide positions within the regions of the 16S rRNA gene, careful selection of an optimal 16S rRNA gene region is critical for studying bacterial phylogeny or assigning correct identity to an isolate. Usually the first 500 bp of 16S rRNA (spanning variable regions V1 to V2) are most commonly used for in-house PCR amplification (52, 53), while primers spanning V4 to V6 were developed to examine bacterial communities in the Baltic Sea (54) and were subsequently introduced into the Illumina 16S metagenomic sequencing protocol. Some fragments of the gene will not provide effective resolution below the genus level for most bacteria (55–57).

The choice of 16S rRNA gene region also depends on the available sequencing technology. While traditional Sanger sequencing produces reads longer than 500 bases, it is low throughput. Next-generation sequencing technologies handle a much larger throughput, but often generate shorter reads. Currently, short-read sequencing technologies are becoming widely used for comparison with 16S rRNA gene databases, particularly for study of microbial communities. However, for some species-level resolution, a full-length 16S rRNA gene sequence may be needed. Novel alternatives to traditional sequencing for obtaining full-length sequences include single-molecule real-time sequencing (58) and Nanopore sequencing (59). Pending a decrease in error rates or bioinformatics solutions, the future holds promise for using long-read technologies for bacterial identification, phylogeny, and community profiling.

Using suboptimal primers can result in selection against certain species or even groups of bacteria (55, 60). Another challenge is identification to species level by 16S rRNA gene fragments; however, challenges in discrimination of Shigella spp. from E. coli, or Streptococcus pneumoniae from Streptococcus mitis, are common to both MALDI-TOF MS and partial 16S rRNA gene sequencing. Further refinements are needed to attain reliable species-level assignment in 16S rRNA gene data sets (61).

sect2.title: 16S rRNA Gene Repositories
sect2.para: Most publicly available databases contain full-length or nearly full-length sequences, as well as shorter fragments, and sequence files are supplemented with metadata describing the taxonomic placement. The most commonly used public databases include SILVA (62), Greengenes (63), and the Ribosomal Database Project (64). The databases are curated and contain high-quality sequence data. Full-length small subunit rRNA sequences can be generated without primers by combining poly(A) tailing and reverse transcription of SSU rRNA molecules with synthetic long-read sequencing, and this approach can reveal a large proportion of novel diversity in complex microbial environments (65). Elimination of primers and generation of full-length 16S rRNA gene sequences may significantly broaden the volume of SSU sequence repositories, thereby increasing the likelihood of successful identification of bacterial isolates. New, improved databases have been published (66), and commercially curated databases (SmartGene, SeqStudio, other) are also available.

sect2.title: Limitations
sect2.para: Identification by 16S rRNA gene sequence has limitations. The intragenomic diversity of 16S rRNA genes is generally below 1%, because homologous recombination effectively maintains homogeneity of these genes within the cell. However, for some bacterial species, the intragenomic heterogeneity of 16S rRNA gene copies is larger than the threshold for defining species, which affects analysis results (67). DNA-DNA hybridization has historically been the taxonomic gold standard, with less than 70% DNA-DNA relatedness designating separate species (68). It is generally accepted that 16S rRNA gene sequences exhibiting less than 97% similarity originate from separate species, but interpretation of identity scores above 97% remains somewhat unclear; several bacterial groups have almost identical 16S rRNA gene sequences but exhibit DNA-DNA hybridization values significantly below the 70% threshold for species differentiation (50, 69, 70). Different 16S rRNA gene identity thresholds for assignment of isolates to species level have been suggested (50, 71).

sect2.title: Improved Taxonomic Resolution at Species Level
sect2.para: Because of high sequence similarity within the 16S rRNA gene in some bacterial genera, species-level identification is not always possible. Expanding the analyzed area to encompass the entire 16S-23S rRNA region markedly improves the taxonomic resolution of closely related bacteria. PCR amplification of an approximately 4,500-bp fragment of the rRNA operon, followed by next-generation sequencing of amplicons, improved the accuracy of species-level identification from 56% with Sanger sequencing of the 16S rRNA gene to 93% using the entire 16S-23S rRNA region (72).

The major limitation of analyzing the 16S-23S rRNA region for bacterial identification and community profiling is the current lack of a reference database containing combined 16S rRNA and 23S rRNA gene sequences. Comprehensive high-quality reference data in repositories are critical for assigning accurate species-level identification to bacterial isolates.

sect3.title: WHOLE-GENOME SEQUENCES
sect3.para: The role of next-generation sequencing as a powerful tool in clinical microbiology is increasingly being demonstrated. Whole-genome sequencing (WGS) can be used in the routine laboratory workflow should typing of pathogens by a method having the highest possible discriminatory power be required, for example during hospital outbreaks (chapter 12). Currently, the use of WGS fits best in a batchwise approach for analyzing samples (73). While this approach is rational for academic or surveillance projects, it is not ideal for routine identification. Portable, real-time devices for DNA and RNA sequencing, such as the MinION from Oxford Nanopore Technologies, may be a solution. WGS is robust for taxonomic resolution at the species level. An average nucleotide identity (ANI) threshold of 95 to 96% has emerged as a putative standard for quantitative delineation of species (5, 6). The Type (strain) Genome Server (TYGS) is an online tool for the calculation of in silico DNA-DNA hybridization values between query WGS and the closest type strain genome (74, 75). It is interconnected with the LPSN database of expert-curated nomenclatural data and adheres to the 70% DNA-DNA relatedness breakpoint for separation of species.

sect3.title: CONCLUSIONS
sect3.para: Major transformations are occurring in clinical bacteriology, where MALDI-TOF MS analysis and total laboratory automation have pushed conventional phenotyping testing close to oblivion; currently, some laboratories may not even perform a simple coagulase test, which previously was decisive for identification of staphylococci. Amplicon-based sequencing of the 16S rRNA gene will expand the scope of the laboratory, from detection of specific pathogens to assessment of the complete microbiota of samples. PCR analyses have replaced culture in clinical virology, and certain PCR tests—such as the rapid detection of common meningitis pathogens—have become indispensable. However, classical culture of clinically important bacteria appears invulnerable in the foreseeable future. When a bacterium is cultured, it can be formally named and fully characterized with the generation of phenotypic antimicrobial susceptibility profiles to guide therapy. Bacterial culture is crucial for elucidation of outbreaks and surveillance of antimicrobial resistance, but molecular methods have potential for rapid delivery of relevant information to clinicians.
